</figure>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Exhibit B: No giant empty cavity under the lid</h3>



<p>And this is what the pie looks like straight out of the oven – Flat lattice, and the inside filled to the brim with apples.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="720" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg" alt="Side photo of freshly cooked apple pie" class="wp-image-77636" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg?resize=125,100 125w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg?resize=85,68 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg?resize=650,520 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Side-photo-freshly-cooked-apple-pie.jpg"></figure>



<p></p>



<p>OK! Ready to see how to make my Apple Pie?? Let’s do this!</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading has-text-align-center" id="h-what-you-need-to-make-apple-pie-filling">What you need to make Apple Pie filling</h2>



<p>Here’s what you need to make the Apple Pie filling. (PS. The egg is out of place, it’s for brushing the pastry!).</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="643" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77294" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg?resize=140,100 140w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg?resize=85,61 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg?resize=650,464 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-ingredients.jpg"></figure>



<ul>
<li><p><strong>Granny Smith apples –</strong> There’s plenty of opinions out there about the best apples for Apple Pie. But for me, Granny Smith is The One, for its tartness and ability to hold its shaped once cooked. This is key to avoiding a mushy filling!</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Brown sugar</strong> – My choice of sugar for caramelly sweetness. I use 1 cup of brown sugar which, to me, provides the perfect level of sweet-but-not-too-sweet.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Apple Pie spices – </strong>Cinnamon, ginger and nutmeg. Mix up your own for better flavour control instead of using a pre-made mix! </p></li>



<li><p><strong>Butter</strong> – Just a dab, for simmering with the apple juices on the tray to make a syrup for the Apple Pie filling.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Salt</strong> – Just a touch, to bring out the other flavours. It doesn’t make it salty at all.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Egg</strong> – Used to brush the pie lid to make it a beautiful and shiny golden brown!</p></li>
</ul>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg" alt="Making Apple Pie" class="wp-image-77313" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_5.jpg"></figure>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h2 class="wp-block-heading has-text-align-center" id="h-apple-pie-crust">Apple Pie crust</h2>



<p>The classic crust used for apple pie is <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/pie-crust-recipe/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">shortcrust</a> and that’s what I use. My recipe is very standard (flour, butter, salt, sugar, water). However the one thing I should probably address is the debate over butter vs vegetable shortening.</p>



<p>Advocates of vegetable shortening (which is a type of fat made from vegetable oil) love how it makes shortcrust pastry ultra-crumbly and flaky.</p>



<p>I have no issues with vegetable shortening per se, except that it is <em>tasteless</em>. So while shortcrust pastry made with butter may not be quite as flaky, it is still flaky enough to me and more importantly, is a whole lot tastier to eat.</p>



<p>And if your mind is going straight to “why not use a combination”?, you must think like me because I tried that too. But I just found it still lacked flavour even using a 50/50 mix.</p>



<p>So, all-butter shortcrust it is! <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/pie-crust-recipe/">Recipe here</a>.</p>



<p>PS. Also – I use a food processor. Because I have hot little hands which melt the little bits of butter as I work with the dough. Food processor = exactly the same results as handmade + superior flakiness + SPEEDIER.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-gallery has-nested-images columns-default is-cropped wp-block-gallery-4 is-layout-flex">
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" data-id="77296" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg" alt="Pie tin with shortcrust pastry for apple pie" class="wp-image-77296" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-shortcrust-pastry.jpg"></figure>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" data-id="77312" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg" alt="Making Apple Pie" class="wp-image-77312" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-pie-making_6.jpg"><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">PS Doing the lattice is EASY. You’ll see below!</figcaption></figure>
</figure>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h2 class="wp-block-heading has-text-align-center" id="h-how-to-make-apple-pie">How to make Apple Pie</h2>



<p>Heads up – there’s a lot of information here because I explain there <em>why</em> and also provide tutorial information so even first-timers can have the confidence to nail the Great Apple Pie!</p>



<p>If you’re a pro, just skip on ahead to the <a href="#wprm-recipe-container-77185">recipe</a> or the <a href="#jump-watch">how-to video</a>, or to <a href="#dozer-life">Dozer</a>. 😂 For everyone else,  come along for the ride.</p>



<div class="wp-block-create-block-rte-info-box-v2 rte-info-box">
<h3 class="wp-block-heading has-text-align-center" id="h-game-plan-my-apple-pie-workflow">Game plan: My Apple Pie workflow</h3>



<ol>
<li><p>Make shortcrust pastry. </p></li>



<li><p>While the pastry-lined pie tin is in the freezer for 2 hours, bake the apple slices.</p></li>



<li><p>While the apple is baking, roll out the pie lid and cut the lattice strips, then refrigerate.</p></li>



<li><p>While the apple slices are cooling, blind bake the pastry and reduce the apple juices to make the syrup.</p></li>



<li><p>Assemble the pie and bake the whole she-bang!</p></li>
</ol>
</div>



<p></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-1-prepare-the-pie-crust">1. Prepare the pie crust</h3>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="510" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77251" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg?resize=176,100 176w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg?resize=85,48 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg?resize=650,368 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/1.-Prepare-the-pie-crust.jpg"></figure>



<ol>
<li><p><strong>Shortcrust dough</strong> – Make a double batch of my (easy!) <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/pie-crust-recipe/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">shortcrust pastry dough</a>. Form two separate discs, wrap and chill for 1 hour in the fridge.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Roll out</strong> – Unwrap one ball of dough and roll out on a lightly floured work surface into a round that is about 5 mm / 1/5″ thick (not too thin, it needs to be sturdy enough for lots of juicy filling!)</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Line pie tin</strong> – I use a 23 cm / 9″ metal pie tin (not a deep dish). Metal is best. You just can’t get a proper crispy base with a glass or ceramic pie tin – we’ve tried. <a href="https://www.amazon.com.au/USA-Pan-Bakeware-Aluminized-9-Inch/dp/B002UNMZNU/ref=asc_df_B002UNMZNU/?tag=googleshopdsk-22&linkCode=df0&hvadid=341792421071&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=16479192514537337884&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9069129&hvtargid=pla-306160406104&psc=1" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">This is the tin</a><strong> </strong>I own, and <a href="https://www.amazon.com.au/Metal-Products-Company-ProBake-Nonstick/dp/B0017WN8A4/ref=sr_1_41?crid=1CA67NY0S0364&keywords=pie%2Bpan&qid=1668826887&qu=eyJxc2MiOiI0LjAyIiwicXNhIjoiMy42MiIsInFzcCI6IjIuODAifQ%3D%3D&s=kitchen&sprefix=pie%2Bpan%2Ckitchen%2C205&sr=1-41&th=1" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">here is</a> a better value one but I haven’t tried it. (Note: There are not affiliate links.)</p><p>To line the pie tin, roll the pastry off the work surface on to the rolling pin, then unroll it over the pie tin. This is not just the simplest technique to transfer the pastry (no tearing!) but you will also avoid stretching the pastry which then causes the crust to shrink when it bakes.</p><p>Drape the pastry into the pie tin, taking care not to stretch it (as noted above).</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Prick pastry and freeze</strong> – Use a fork to gently prick the base around 30 times (don’t go all the way through). This helps prevent the base from bubbling up when baking which can cause pie juice leakages.</p><p>Wrap the pie tin in cling wrap and freeze for 2 hours. You can actually even leave it there frozen for up to 1 month (probably longer, I just haven’t tried).</p><p>Freezing pastry is a terrific technique I learned from my French pastry chef teacher <a href="https://jenniferpogmore.com" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Jennifer Pogmore</a> (she’s based in France and we work remotely together!) Baking a pastry from frozen results in basically zero pastry shrinkage – and excellent pro tip!</p><p>It’s extra-important to avoid pie crusts shrinking with a fully-loaded apple pie because it can lead to a broken crust when the filled pie is baked! Why? Well, imagine all the weight of all that filling pressing against a crust that has shrunk away and is no longer reinforced by the pie tin walls. It can crack like a burst dam. Apple juices seep under the crust which then glues the crust to the pie tin … disaster! (Clearly you can tell I speak from experience 😂).</p></li>
</ol>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-2-blind-bake-the-crust">2. Blind bake the crust</h3>



<p>Blind baking (par baking) is key to ensure the crust is not just crispy, but also fully cooked. We tried numerous variations without blind baking the crust. The results were mixed. For some, the base was soggy, and for other attempts, either the base and or/sides were not fully cooked.</p>



<p>Conclusion: blind baking is essential! Here’s how to do it.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="755" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77258" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg?resize=119,100 119w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg?resize=85,71 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg?resize=650,545 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/2.-Blind-baking.jpg"></figure>



<ol>
<li><p><strong>Cover with paper </strong>– Cover the frozen pie crust with two overlapping large sheets of baking/parchment paper arranged in a “X”. Excess paper hanging over the edges is necessary to protect the pie rim from browning too fast as well as having plenty to grip so you can remove the hot baking beads safely (see below).</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Baking beads</strong> – Fill with baking beads until level to the rim. These beads weigh down the base as well as press the pastry against the sides of the pie tin so it prevents the pastry from shrinking. (Read section above for why pastry shrinkage is undesirable for Apple Pie!)</p><p>No baking beads? Use uncooked rice or dried beans. Keep for re-use indefinitely.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Bake </strong>for 25 minutes at 200°C / 400°F (180°C fan). </p></li>



<li><p><strong>Remove</strong> the baking beads using the paper overhang to lift out the paper and transfer them to a heatproof bowl.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Egg wash – </strong>Brush the base and sides (but not rim) lightly with whisked egg. This is a crispy base insurance step. When the egg cooks, it forms a thin water-resistant “barrier” to help prevent the pastry from absorbing the juices.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Bake uncovered</strong> for a further 5 minutes then remove from oven. The pie crust should be light golden and look fully cooked.</p><p>Leave to cool for 15 minutes before filling with the Apple Pie Filling. This is another crispy base insurance step, ie. hot pastry absorbs liquid more.</p></li>
</ol>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-3-baking-apple-slices">3. Baking apple slices</h3>



<p>Baking the apple slices is the key step for the Perfect Apple Pie. Read the reasons why in the section above!</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="506" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77271" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg?resize=178,100 178w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg?resize=85,48 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg?resize=650,365 650w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg?resize=480,270 480w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-3.jpg"></figure>



<ol>
<li><p><strong>Slice apples</strong> – Core the apples using your chosen method. If you’re an apple-cooking fiend like myself, you’ll have an apple corer. If not, you can just core the apples using whatever method best works for you. </p><p>Peel then halve the apples. Now place them flat side-down and cut into 1cm / 0.4″ thick slices. Try to cut them as evenly as possible so they cook evenly.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Toss with spices and sugar – </strong>Put the apple slices in a large bowl. Mix the sugar and spices in a separate small bowl (I know you just want to dump them straight in but then the spices don’t disperse evenly). Now sprinkle the mixture over the apple slices and use your hands to toss well, separating the apple slices as needed so they are evenly coated.</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="252" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77272" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg?resize=357,100 357w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg?resize=85,24 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg?resize=650,182 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-1.jpg"></figure>



<ol start="3">
<li><p><strong>Bake – </strong>Spread across 2 trays and bake at 180°C/350°F (160°C fan) until the apples are tender but not mushy. The bake time will vary from 15 minutes to 40 minutes. An interesting discovery when we were testing this recipe as Granny Smith apples here in Australia take 40 minutes whereas in France, they take just 15 minutes. Perhaps this is due to local apple variations? <em>Amazing! </em></p><p>A simple lesson learned: Check your apple doneness early. Easy!</p><p><strong>What the done apples should be like</strong>: The apple slices should be tender and offer no resistance when you pierce them with a knife. However, you don’t want them <em>mushy</em>. They will be a bit delicate when hot out of the oven but will firm up as they cool. They won’t cook much more once inside the pie, that step is more about melding everything together to become a juicy pie filling.</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="251" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77273" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg?resize=359,100 359w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg?resize=85,24 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg?resize=650,181 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-2.jpg"></figure>



<ol start="4">
<li><p><strong>Apple juices</strong> – Drain the apple juices on the trays into a saucepan. No need to be fussy here, just tilt the tray and use a spatula to hold back the apple slices while you drain off as much as you can. If there’s some left on the tray that’s ok – we will just add it later.</p><p>You should have around 1/2 cup of juices. Some days though I have less, other days I have more. It doesn’t matter because we are reducing it in the next step to a specific amount.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Make syrup </strong>–<strong> </strong>Add the butter to the apple juices and simmer on low heat until it reduces to 1/3 cup (80 ml) and becomes a syrupy consistency. It might take 1 minute if you only had around 1/3 cup, or 5 minutes if you started with 1/2 cup or more.</p><p>Reducing the apple juices to a syrup serves 2 purposes. Firstly, we are not wasting free flavour – never, we are getting apple flavour to the max! It made me want to cry every time I read an Apple Pie recipe that directed people to discard apple juices.</p><p>Secondly, by reducing the apple juices to a thicker syrup, it will cling to the apple pieces better and will not soak into the base as much. Which means – yup, you guessed it – crispy base!</p><p>Once the syrup is ready, set aside to cool.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Cool apples </strong>– Meanwhile, also set the cooked apple slices aside to cool. This will make them less delicate to handle and also ensures they don’t overcook into mush when baked inside the pie in the 45 minute cook time required for the pastry lid to cook.</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="1200" height="709" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?w=900" alt="" class="wp-image-77274" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg 1200w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?resize=169,100 169w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?resize=900,532 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?resize=85,50 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?resize=650,384 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/3.-Baking-apples-4.jpg?w=900"></figure>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-4-fill-the-pie">4. Fill the pie</h3>



<p>OK! We’re on the home stretch here to the best part: cooking but more importantly, EATING IT!!!</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="507" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77280" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg?resize=178,100 178w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg?resize=85,48 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg?resize=650,366 650w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg?resize=480,270 480w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie.jpg"></figure>



<ol>
<li><p><strong>Fill</strong> the pie crust with 2/3 of the cooled apple slices. I find using a spatula or egg flip to scoop them up is the best way to handle them. Place them in the pie crust and press down lightly to remove air pockets.</p><p>With the remaining apple, firstly arrange some in a heap in the centre to create a slight mound. Then keep layering the rest of the apple slices over the top of the filling. You can see in my photo I’ve placed them slightly overlapping in a neat arrangement. You don’t need to do that!</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Pour over</strong> the apple syrup and any residual juices left on the tray.</p></li>
</ol>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-5-lattice-tutorial">5. Lattice tutorial!</h3>



<p>OK! I know we all want our Apple Pies to sport the neat, criss-cross woven pastry lid like we see in every classic Apple Pie photo ever. So here’s a little pie lattice tutorial.  I promise it’s not hard!</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="507" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77283" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg?resize=178,100 178w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg?resize=85,48 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg?resize=650,366 650w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg?resize=480,270 480w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-1.jpg"></figure>



<ol>
<li><p><strong>Roll out</strong> the pie lid dough on a lightly floured work surface to 3 mm / 1/8″ thick. You don’t want it too thick or it will not cook through by the time the lid surface is a beautiful golden colour.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Cut</strong> 12 x 2.5cm / 1″ strips. I use a ruler and a small sharp knife that I run along the ruler to cut the strips.</p><p>I try to do this step while the apples are baking, returning the strips to the fridge (covered in cling wrap) until required.</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1014" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77286" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg?resize=89,100 89w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg?resize=85,96 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg?resize=650,732 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/How-to-do-lattice-for-apple-pie-2.jpg"></figure>



<ol start="3">
<li><p><strong>Forming the lattice – </strong>Place 6 pastry strips in the same direction on top of the filling, evenly spaced apart.</p><p>Fold back every 2nd strip to halfway. Place a strip of pastry perpendicular to the laid strips, right up the strips are folded. Now unfold the strips to return them to how they were. Next, fold up the alternative strips you didn’t fold first time around, and place another strip across the pie in the same way. Repeat with one more strip. Rotate the pie and repeat with the remaining 3 strips to do the other half of the pie. Obviously, this is a good time to watch the <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/apple-pie-recipe/#jump-watch">video</a> to see how it’s done!</p><p><strong>Trim</strong> excess strip pastry using scissors or a small sharp knife.</p><p><strong>Seal</strong> by using water and pressing the strips against the crust to adhere. I find it easiest just to use my finger.</p></li>
</ol>



<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity">



<h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-6-bake-it">6. Bake it!</h3>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="245" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77290" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg?resize=367,100 367w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg?resize=85,23 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg?resize=650,177 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a-copy.jpg"></figure>



<ol start="1">
<li><p><strong>Egg wash</strong> – Brush the lattice with egg wash, taking care to avoid the cooked pie rim (else it will get overly brown). Also ensure you don’t end up with pools of egg in the lattice joins, which will be unsightly.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Sugar sprinkle</strong> – Then sprinkle with sugar. We use regular sugar and not caster/superfine so we’ll have lovely sparkly sugar crystals bejewelling our lid.</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="253" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-77291" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg?resize=356,100 356w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg?resize=85,24 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg?resize=650,183 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/4-Assembling-apple-pie-2a.jpg"></figure>



<ol start="3">
<li><p><strong>Bake</strong> for 45 minutes until the pastry is golden and you see the apple juices bubbling inside.</p></li>



<li><p><strong>Cool</strong> – Fully cool for at least 3 hours before cutting to serve. If you want to serve after this, you’ll need to cut and serve it out of the pie tin because the pie will not be stable enough to turn out whole. The slices will also be a little rustic. 🙂 Such is the nature of freshly made pies!</p><p><strong>Neat slices</strong> – If you would prefer to serve neater slices as pictured, just refrigerate the pie overnight. It will firm up and become sturdy enough to turn out onto a plate and cut neat slices. Leaving overnight also gives the pie filling flavours a chance to meld together even more.</p><p>To then reheat, cover with foil and reheat in the oven (10 minutes at 180°C/350°F) or use the microwave for a speedy option (1 minute). And yes, the base stays crisp!</p></li>
</ol>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1260" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg" alt="Overhead photo of serving apple pie" class="wp-image-77302" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg?resize=71,100 71w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg?resize=85,119 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg?resize=650,910 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_1.jpg"></figure>



<p>Here’s a close up of the cut apple pie after it’s rested overnight and has been reheated in the oven. It’s still nice and juicy, and cuts neatly.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg" alt="Close up slice of apple pie" class="wp-image-77303" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_0.jpg"></figure>



<p>Serving without vanilla ice cream is not even an option. It goes without saying – right??!! Maybe with cream too – or would that take it over the top?</p>



<figure class="wp-block-gallery has-nested-images columns-default is-cropped wp-block-gallery-6 is-layout-flex">
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" data-id="77301" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg" alt="Overhead photo of slice of Apple Pie" class="wp-image-77301" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_2.jpg"></figure>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img decoding="async" loading="lazy" width="900" height="1125" data-id="77299" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg" alt="Eating Apple Pie" class="wp-image-77299" srcset="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg 900w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg?resize=80,100 80w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg?resize=85,106 85w, https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg?resize=650,813 650w" sizes="(min-width: 768px) 650px, (max-width: 320px) 93.75vw, 97.39vw" data-pin-media="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Apple-Pie_7.jpg"></figure>
</figure>



<p>And there you have it. My perfect Apple Pie! A strange time to share it perhaps, heading into Australian summer. But she cannot always choose when she will <em>finally</em> be happy with a recipe. Still, she is chuffed that she managed to squeeze this in just before Thanksgiving – enjoy, my American friends! <strong><em>– Nagi x</em></strong></p>



<p>PS. I don’t know why I’m writing about myself in the 3rd person. Note to self: come back and fix this!</p>

	<div class="wprm-entry-content">

		<div class="wprm-recipe-summary wprm-block-text-normal"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Recipe video above. </strong>Basic Apple Pie recipes just call for piling raw apples in an uncooked pie crust. It will work … but the crust will have raw patches, be soggy, the apples unevenly cooked and you'll have a giant empty cavity under the pie lid. Hmm.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div><span style="display: block;">If, like me, that's not good enough for you, make my Perfect Apple Pie! The trick: bake the apples for the filling first and blind bake your crust. Result? Superior flavour, perfectly cooked apple filling, a crispy base and no unsightly gaping cave under your pie lid!</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div><span style="display: block;"><strong>NOTE: </strong>Saddened to see mixed reviews where the wrong apple types has been used. This recipe is made for Granny Smith Apples! Other apples are not juicy enough or too soft. Please follow the recipe!</span></div>

		<div class="wprm-recipe-instructions-container wprm-recipe-77185-instructions-container wprm-block-text-normal" data-recipe="77185"><h3 class="wprm-recipe-header wprm-recipe-instructions-header wprm-block-text-normal wprm-align-left wprm-header-decoration-none" style="">Instructions</h3><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Pie crust:</h4><ul class="wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Shortcrust:</strong> Make a double batch of my <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/pie-crust-recipe/" target="_blank">shortcrust pastry recipe</a>. Form the dough discs, wrap and refrigerate per the recipe.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Line tin: </strong>Roll out one dough just large enough to fit a 23cm/9" metal pie tin, following directions in the <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/pie-crust-recipe/" target="_blank">shortcrust recipe</a>. You want the base relatively thick so it's sturdy. Trim off excess pastry, prick the base 30 times with a fork (don't pierce through).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-2" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Freeze </strong>(Note 4)<strong>: </strong>Cover with cling wrap and freeze for 2 hours. </span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-3" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;">While crust is freezing, make apple filling. Then continue with pie crust steps.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-4" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Preheat </strong>oven to 200°C / 400°F (180°C fan).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-5" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Blind bake</strong> (Note 5): Place two large sheets of baking/parchment paper in a "X" over the pie tin then fill with baking beads (Note 4). Bake 25 minutes. </span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-6" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Egg wash </strong>(Note 5)<strong>:</strong> Remove from oven. Use paper excess to remove beads into a bowl. Brush base and sides (not rim) lightly with whisked egg. Return crust to oven for 5 minutes.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-0-7" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Cool: </strong>Crust should be light golden and look fully cooked. Cool 15 minutes before filling.</span></div></li></ul></div><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Lattice <strong>(Note 6 for full lid):</strong></h4><ul class="wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-1-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;">Remove remaining dough from fridge 30 minutes prior. Roll out to 3 mm / 1/8" thick and cut into 12 x  2.5cm/1" strips. Transfer to board, cover with cling wrap and refrigerate until required.</span></div></li></ul></div><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Apple Pie Filling:</h4><ul class="wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Preheat</strong> oven to 180°C / 350°F (160°C fan).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Spice mix</strong>: Mix the sugar, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg and salt in a bowl.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-2" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Toss: </strong>In a large bowl, sprinkle spice mix over apple slices. Toss well with hands, separating pieces that are stuck together.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-3" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Bake:</strong> Spread across 2 large trays. Bake until soft but still holding form – check first at 15 min, and every 5 mins thereafter (mine take 40 min – Note 7). Do not stir or rotate trays.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-4" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Drain off juices:</strong> Remove trays from oven. Using a spatula to hold the apples back, pour apple juices into a saucepan (drain off what you can, you don't need every drop).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-5" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Cool apple:</strong> Leave apple slices to cool on the tray, about 15 minutes.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-2-6" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Apple syrup:</strong> Add butter to apple juice saucepan and simmer on low heat until it reduces to 1/3 cup (80 ml), becoming syrupy. This might take 1 minute if you didn't start with much juices, or 3 – 5 minutes if you started with 1/2 cup or more juices. Remove from stove and let cool.</span></div></li></ul></div><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Assemble and bake:</h4><ul class="wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Turn oven up</strong> to 200°C/400°F (180°C fan).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Fill:</strong> Use a spatula or egg flip to scoop up apple slices. Fill the pie crust with 2/3 of the apples, gently pressing out air pockets. Then arrange the remaining apples on top so they mound slightly at the centre. Pour apple syrup over the slices and any residual juices from the baking trays.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-2" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Pastry lattice or lid: </strong>Top with pastry lattice – see in post for my method. Trim excess, and press to adhere on to pie crust rim using water to seal. Brush lattice with egg wash (avoid the pie rim else it will over-brown there), ensuring you don't get pools of egg in the joins. Sprinkle with sugar.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-3" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Bake</strong> 45 minutes or until the pastry is golden and you see the syrup bubbling through the lattice.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-4" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Serving fresh:</strong> Cool at least 3 hours before cutting to serve!</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-5" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;"><strong>Option for neat slices: </strong>After cooling, refrigerate overnight. Turn pie out of pie dish (it's sturdy enough once cooled). Then you can cut neat slices. Place on a tray, cover with foil and reheat for 10 minutes in a 180°C/350°F oven (or microwave in emergency!).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-77185-step-3-6" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: decimal;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text"><span style="display: block;">In either case serve with vanilla ice cream, always!</span></div></li></ul></div></div>
		
		<div class="wprm-recipe-notes-container wprm-block-text-normal"><h3 class="wprm-recipe-header wprm-recipe-notes-header wprm-block-text-normal wprm-align-left wprm-header-decoration-none" style=""><i class="fas fa-pencil"></i> Recipe Notes:</h3><div class="wprm-recipe-notes"><span style="display: block;"><span data-slate-node="text"><strong>MY WORKFLOW: </strong></span><span data-slate-node="text" data-slate-fragment="">While pastry lined pie tin is in the freezer, bake apples. Meanwhile, roll out lattice. While baked apples are cooling, blind bake pie crust and reduce apple syrup. Then assemble pie and bake!</span></span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>1. Crust –</strong> If using store-bought pie crust, follow packet directions.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>2. Granny Smith</strong> is my choice for apple pie for its tart flavour which plays so well with the sugar and spices. Also because it holds its form well when cooked (rather than turning into baby food).</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>PLEASE </strong>do not make this pie with other types of apples, I cannot guarantee outcome as some varieties are not juicy enough (= dry filling) or are too soft!</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>3. Sugar</strong> for a sparkling crust. Optional.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>4. Freezing</strong> prevents pastry shrinkage. It really works and is worth doing. A neat trick taught to me by my French pastry chef teacher <a href="https://jenniferpogmore.com/">Jennifer Pogmore</a>. Freeze overnight or up to 1 month! This step is key for apple pie because crust shrinkage = high risk of breakage once filled (because crust is no longer pressed again pie tin wall for support).</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;">Baking beads also helps prevent pastry shrinkage. Don’t have any? Use uncooked rice grains or dried beans. Save for re-use another time!</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>5. Par baking</strong> the crust is key for ensuring the pie crust is fully cooked and crisp. If you start with raw dough, you will end up with some raw patches whether on the base or sides, or both, and/or soggy base.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>Egg wash</strong> on blind baked crust also helps keep the base crispy as it forms a bit of a water-resistant barrier.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>6. Full pie lid option</strong> (instead of lattice) – Roll out pastry and don’t cut strips. Seal to rim using water, cut 2.5cm/1″ cross in centre to allow steam to escape. Brush with egg and sprinkle with sugar. Bake per recipe.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>7. Apple baking time</strong> – Start checking your apples at the 15 minute mark as we discovered during testing that the same variety of apples differ drastically in cook times. In France (where Jennifer resides), it only takes 15 minutes. Mine take 40 minutes. So just start checking early! Note: Apple does not soften much more once inside the pie crust so get the texture right during this step.</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>8. Recipe credits – </strong>Many thanks to my French pastry chef teacher <a href="https://jenniferpogmore.com/">Jennifer Pogmore</a> and RecipeTin’s <a href="https://www.recipetineats.com/chef-jean-baptiste-alexandre/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Chef JB</a> for their assistance and expertise to bring my vision of the perfect Apple Pie to life. We did it!!!</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>9. Leftover </strong>apple pie will keep for up to 4 days in the fridge though it is at its prime in the first 24 hours after baking. Freezing – I haven’t tried. When I get a chanace I will try then update this note!</span><div class="wprm-spacer"></div>
<span style="display: block;"><strong>10. Nutrition</strong> – Pie only without ice cream or cream.</span></div></div>

	</div>

			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/96118854062ebebfe81a88208137acb2?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/96118854062ebebfe81a88208137acb2?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Ashley Warner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >November 8, 2023 at 4:40 pm</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p>I’m sure this has been done but I am attempting a combination of this recipe and your apple crumble, it’s essentially an apple pie with the crumble topping instead of shortbread, any advice for this?</p>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-1521558">
	<article id="article-comment-1521558">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c1242480280a8d105734319513c2ae9f?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c1242480280a8d105734319513c2ae9f?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Esther</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >October 17, 2023 at 12:28 pm</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p>This is a very good apple pie but not exceptional enough to be worth all the extra work involved in making it.  Even using a frozen pie crust, it took me over 4 hours to prepare the filling, parable the crust, precook the filling, assemble the pie and bake it.  That did not include cooling time.  I like your recipes because they usually are tasty and not too picky to make.  If you include a special step, it usually has an excellent result.  This recipe was too picky and time consuming s<br />
I I won’t bother making it again.  Sorry, Nagi. You missed it this time.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1521558' data-commentid="1521558" data-postid="76801" data-belowelement="article-comment-1521558" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Esther" aria-label='Reply to Esther'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<article id="article-comment-1506888">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/68b6bb0971586eb539c3faabbdef9249?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/68b6bb0971586eb539c3faabbdef9249?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Melanie</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >September 3, 2023 at 2:29 pm</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p>My only advice with this apple pie is do yourself a favour & double the apple quantities. If your house is anything like mine, most of the filling was stollen before it made it into the pie crust! That & I couldn’t help myself & added lemon zest to the pastry.<br />
Delicious! Thanks Nagi & Team another successful Father’s Day apple pie. 😍🍏🥧</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-1495037">
	<article id="article-comment-1495037">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cd47e1033c7c335ee891f831a637c744?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cd47e1033c7c335ee891f831a637c744?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Toni</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >August 21, 2023 at 10:37 am</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p><img class="wprm-comment-rating" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/plugins/wp-recipe-maker/assets/icons/rating/stars-4.svg" alt="4 stars" width="80" height="16" /><br />
I made this, firstly it was delicious, but I fight with the pastry, the same thing happened to me as other comments here, I make pastry all the time but cant seem to master the rolling without cracking, once pastry out of the fridge it constantly cracks. It doesnt roll out to fit pan otherwise its too thin. Cant try and curve the edges as it isnt enough to cover and it crumbles off when you try. So I am patching with the cut offs. Even adding more water doesnt work for me.  Maybe I might try  leave it for about 5 min from the fridge before rolling it so not so Cold? The freezer part DID work as it didn’t shrink. In the end I got there. I will keep trying as I wont let this beat me.</p>
		</div>

				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cee3b10a6f0b48c1c338c9f4dad127c8?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cee3b10a6f0b48c1c338c9f4dad127c8?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Ros</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >December 4, 2022 at 8:22 am</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p>I just made this pie. I’ve made a lot in my lifetime because my family is especially fond of them. This was really good. The extra steps of baking the apple and making the syrup is worth it! Thanks Nagi (and Dozer – my dog Lucy says woof!)</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1398487' data-commentid="1398487" data-postid="76801" data-belowelement="article-comment-1398487" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Ros" aria-label='Reply to Ros'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-1398301">
	<article id="article-comment-1398301">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a382793b635ad96c31a031024c21cbdf?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a382793b635ad96c31a031024c21cbdf?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Sherie Dracup</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >December 4, 2022 at 1:22 am</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p><img class="wprm-comment-rating" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/wp-content/plugins/wp-recipe-maker/assets/icons/rating/stars-3.svg" alt="3 stars" width="80" height="16" /><br />
I made the pie, made a mess of the pastry bottom, for which I probably did something wrong.  Lattice looked great, but filling was too dry.  Found it messy to bake the apples, but the flavour was wonderful.  Have fried before with success. I don’t think I will try again.  I love all the other recipes of yours that I have tried.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1398301' data-commentid="1398301" data-postid="76801" data-belowelement="article-comment-1398301" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Sherie Dracup" aria-label='Reply to Sherie Dracup'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/31c25db820fe6d9bdc2ab715fbea86dc?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/31c25db820fe6d9bdc2ab715fbea86dc?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Gerald</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

I’ve never been happy with apple pie recipes I’ve tried in the past – PEOPLE, THIS IS A KEEPER! Best apple pie I’ve ever had!</p>
		</div>

		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0e3a1430aea5966ec74d802103a6b022?s=40&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0e3a1430aea5966ec74d802103a6b022?s=80&d=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.recipetineats.com%2Fwp-content%2Fthemes%2Fonce-coupled-recipe-tin-eats%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Favatar-guest-temp-cache-bust-duplicate.png&r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-40 photo' height='40' width='40' loading='lazy' decoding='async'/><span class="comment-author-name">Andrew</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time"><a >November 29, 2022 at 11:01 pm</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content">
			
			<p>Kinda erked by the prospect of payinf $35 for a pie tin but am thinking of getting a Lodge double dutch oven (<a href="https://www.lodgecastiron.com/product/double-dutch-oven" rel="nofollow ugc">https://www.lodgecastiron.com/product/double-dutch-oven</a>) to make your bread recipe. Also erked by its price ($150) but the more uses I find for it the more palatable that gets.</p>
<p>This leads me to my question: would using the lid as a pie tin work or would it retain too much heat (and burn it or something)?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1368684' data-commentid="1368684" data-postid="76801" data-belowelement="article-comment-1368684" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Andrew" aria-label='Reply to Andrew'>Reply</a></div>

<script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.recipetineats.com/_static/??-eJyFjEsOwjAMBS+EsaAStAvEUVBJDHJbO5aTiOsTVeqibFi+zwx+DELSQlrQlvpmzdgqp8BGIONMjpFzG+tz4QCSIrkep3zA/ySYk3CVncE8/eJSYTOMM2ehgg/WsAV4+XqMjbvL7XQZhq7vr+du+gLNEEY+" ></script><style type="text/css">.wprm-recipe-recipe-tin-eats {
    background-color: #f6f5f3; /*wprm_background type=color*/
    border-width: 4px; /*wprm_border_width type=size*/
    border-style: solid; /*wprm_border_style type=border*/
    border-color: #f6f5f3; /*wprm_border type=color*/
    border-radius: 0px; /*wprm_border_radius type=size*/
    padding: 12px;
}

/* -------- [ OC Code ] -------- */

/* [ Containers ] */

.wprm-print {
    width: 650px;
    max-width: calc(100% - 20px);
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 0;
}

.wprm-recipe {
    font-size: 15px;
    overflow: visible;
}

.wprm-recipe a {
    color: #f4796c;
    text-decoration: underline;
}

.wprm-recipe-container { /* only in non-print displays */
    clear: both;
    margin: 8px 0 20px;
}

.wprm-recipe-container:focus {
    outline: 0; /* remove, as it shows when using the "jump" button */
}

/* [ CTA ] */

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-cta {
    margin-bottom: 12px;
    font-size: 15px;
}

.wprm-print .wprm-recipe-cta {
    display: none;
}

.wprm-recipe-cta-header {
    font-size: 19px;
    font-weight: 800;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
    color: #183354;
}

body:not(.wprm-print) .wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-cta:first-letter {
    font-size: 19px;
} /* Fix for Galaxy S7, S8 Internet issue where letter drops down. */

/* [ Card ] */

.wprm-recipe-recipe-tin-eats {
    padding: 0 16px;
    margin: 80px auto 12px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe-recipe-tin-eats {
        padding: 0 32px;
        position: relative;
    }
}

/* [ Header ] */

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-header {
    text-align: center;
    color: #fff;
    background: #112942;
    margin: -4px -20px 0;
    padding: 16px 20px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-header {
        margin-left: -36px;
        margin-right: -36px;
        padding-left: 36px;
        padding-right: 36px;
    }
}

/* Image */

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-image {
    max-width: 200px;
    margin: -80px auto 16px;
    border: 6px solid #112942;
    border-radius: 100%;
    display: block;
    overflow: hidden;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-image .size-placement-recipe {
    border-radius: 100%;
}

/* Text */

.wprm-block-text-normal {
    font-weight: 500;
}

.wprm-recipe-details-label {
    min-width: auto !important;
}

/* Title */

.wprm-recipe-name {
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 26px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe-name {
        font-size: 32px;
    }
}

/* Info */

.wprm-entry-info {
    text-align: center;
    margin: 12px 0 0;
    font-size: 12px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-entry-info {
        clear: both;
        font-size: 14px;
    }
}

.wprm-entry-info .wprm-recipe-author-container,
.wprm-entry-info .wprm-recipe-time-container {
    display: inline-block;
    margin: 0 4px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-details-unit {
    font-size: 1em;
}

.wprm-recipe-author {
    margin-left: 4px;
}

.wprm-entry-info .svg-inline--fa {
    margin-right: 2px;
}

/* Ratings */

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-rating {
        margin: 8px 0 0;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-rating-star {
    margin: 0 4px;
    font-size: 19px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-rating-star polygon {
    stroke: #f4796c;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-rating-star.wprm-rating-star-full polygon {
    fill: #f4796c;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-rating-details {
    display: inline-block;
    margin-left: 8px;
    font-size: 11px;
    position: relative;
    top: -2px;
}

/* [ Servings ] */

.wprm-entry-servings {
    color: #fff;
    background: #1d3c5c;
    text-align: center;
    margin: 0 -20px;
    padding: 8px 20px;
    line-height: 1.4;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-entry-servings {
        margin-left: -36px;
        margin-right: -36px;
        padding-left: 36px;
        padding-right: 36px;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe-servings-container {
    display: inline-block;
    font-size: 16px;
    line-height: 1;
    margin-top: -4px;
    vertical-align: middle;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-servings-container .wprm-recipe-servings-link .wprm-recipe-servings {
    color: #fff;
    font-weight: 800;
    font-size: 22px;
    padding: 4px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 465px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-servings-container .wprm-recipe-servings-link .wprm-recipe-servings {
        margin-left: 4px;
    }
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-servings-container .wprm-recipe-servings-link .wprm-recipe-servings {
        padding: 4px 8px;
    }
}

.serving-tooltip {
    display: inline-block;
    margin-left: 0;
    font-style: italic;
    font-size: 14px;
    line-height: 1.4;
    vertical-align: middle;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 465px) {
    .serving-tooltip {
        vertical-align: top;
        margin-left: 0px;
    }
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .serving-tooltip {
        font-size: 16px;
    }
}

/* [ Buttons ] */

.wprm-entry-buttons .wprm-recipe-print,
.wprm-entry-buttons .dpsp-shortcode-wrapper {
    vertical-align: middle;
    margin-bottom: 8px !important;
}

.wprm-print .wprm-entry-buttons {
    display: none;
}

.wprm-entry-buttons {
    margin: 20px 0;
    text-align: center;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-entry-buttons {
        margin: 24px 0 20px;
    }
}

.wprm-entry-buttons .wprm-recipe-link {
    display: inline-block;
    color: #183354 !important;
    background: #dce8e8;
    font-weight: 800;
    font-size: 18px;
    padding: 8px 24px;
    border-radius: 40px;
}

.wprm-entry-buttons .wprm-recipe-link .svg-inline--fa {
    margin-right: 4px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 1024px) {
    .wprm-entry-buttons .wprm-recipe-link {
        padding: 4px 36px;
    }

    .wprm-entry-buttons .wprm-recipe-link:hover {
        color: #fff !important;
        background: #183354;
    }
}

/* Summary */

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-summary {
    font-style: italic;
}

/* [ Content ] */

.wprm-entry-content {
    clear: both;
}

/* Ingredient & Instruction Groups */

.wprm-recipe-container .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content .wprm-recipe-header {
    font-family: 'Lora', serif;
    font-weight: 700;
    font-size: 18px;
    text-transform: none;
    letter-spacing: 0;
    color: #f4796c;
    margin-top: 20px;
    margin-bottom: 8px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-group-name {
    font-size: 14px !important;
    margin-top: 16px !important;
    margin-bottom: 4px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-instructions-container .wprm-recipe-group-name {
    margin-bottom: 8px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content li {
    line-height: 1.6;
    margin-left: 24px;
    margin-bottom: 4px;
}

.wprm-recipe-ingredients .wprm-checkbox {
    margin-top: 2px;
    margin-left: -4px;
}

.wprm-recipe-ingredient-notes {
    font-size: 1em;
}

.wprm-recipe-ingredients-container .wprm-recipe-ingredient-notes-faded {
    opacity: 1;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content .wprm-recipe-instructions {
    margin-left: 32px;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content .wprm-recipe-instruction {
    margin-left: 0;
    list-style-type: none !important;
    counter-increment: instruction-counter;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content .wprm-recipe-instruction::before {
    content: counter(instruction-counter);
    display: block;
    float: left;
    width: 20px;
    height: 20px;
    line-height: 20px;
    text-align: center;
    color: #fff;
    background: #183354;
    border-radius: 100%;
    margin-top: 2px;
    margin-left: -32px;
    font-weight: 800;
    font-size: 11px;
}

/* Notes */

.wprm-recipe-notes-container {
    margin: 12px -12px;
    background: #fff;
    padding: 12px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe-notes-container {
        margin: 24px -16px;
        padding: 16px;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe-container .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-content .wprm-recipe-notes-header {
    margin-top: 0;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-notes-container ol,
.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-notes-container ul {
    margin-left: 0;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-notes-container ul li::before {
    content: '' !important;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-notes-container ol li {
    counter-increment: note-counter;
    margin-left: 28px;
}

.single .wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-notes-container .wprm-recipe-notes ol li::before {
    content: counter(note-counter) !important;
    display: block;
    background: #f4796c;
    margin-top: 2px;
}

/* [ Nutrition ] */

.wprm-nutrition-label-container {
    border: 1px solid #dee0df;
    padding: 16px;
    line-height: 1.6;
    margin: 12px 0;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-nutrition-label-container {
        margin: 16px 0;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe-notes-container .wprm-nutrition-label-container {
    border: 0;
    padding: 0;
    line-height: 1;
    margin: 0;
}

.wprm-recipe-container .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-nutrition .wprm-recipe-header {
    float: left;
    margin: 19px 12px 0 16px;
}

.wprm-nutrition-label-text-nutrition-container {
    display: inline-block;
    margin-right: 8px;
}

.wprm-nutrition-label-text-nutrition-label {
    color: #3d3d3d !important;
    font-weight: 800;
}

.wprm-nutrition-label-text-nutrition-value,
.wprm-nutrition-label-text-nutrition-unit,
.wprm-nutrition-label-text-nutrition-daily {
    color: #b7b2ac !important;
}

/* [ Tags ] */

.wprm-entry-tags {
    color: #b7b2ac;
    font-size: 12px;
    line-height: 1.2;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-recipe-tag-container {
    display: inline;
    margin-right: 4px;
}

.wprm-recipe-tag-container .wprm-recipe-details-label {
    margin-right: 2px;
}

/* [ Footer ] */

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer {
    color: #fff;
    background: #112942;
    text-align: center;
    margin: 20px -20px 0;
    padding: 20px;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer {
        margin-left: -36px;
        margin-right: -36px;
        padding-left: 28px 36px;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer a {
    color: #fff !important;
    text-decoration: underline !important;
}

@media screen and (min-width: 768px) {
    .wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer a:hover {
        cursor: pointer;
        text-decoration: none;
    }
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer .wprm-call-to-action {
    display: block;
    padding: 0 !important;
    line-height: 1.6;
}

.wprm-recipe .wprm-entry-footer .wprm-call-to-action .wprm-call-to-action-icon {
    color: #fff;
    background: #f4796c;
    display: block;
    width: 48px;
    height: 48px;
    line-height: 1;
    border-radius: 100%;
    margin: -36px auto 8px;
    font-size: 19px;
    padding: 12px 0;
}
