Sprinkle the cinnamon, nutmeg and salt over the apples. Stir to combine. Set aside while you make the pie crust.","name":"Add the vanilla, \u00bc cup flour, granulated sugar and brown sugar to the bowl with the apples. Sprinkle the cinnamon, nutmeg and salt over the apples. Stir to combine. Set aside while you make the pie crust.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-0-1"}]},{"@type":"HowToSection","name":"Make the Pie Crust","itemListElement":[{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Place the flour, sugar and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the steel blade. (Alternatively, the pie crust dough can be made by hand in a large bowl using a pastry cutter or your fingers to cut in the butter.)","name":"Place the flour, sugar and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the steel blade. (Alternatively, the pie crust dough can be made by hand in a large bowl using a pastry cutter or your fingers to cut in the butter.)","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-0"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Pulse to combine the dry ingredients. Add the cold butter cubes and pulse about 10 times, until the largest butter pieces are the size of small peas.","name":"Pulse to combine the dry ingredients. Add the cold butter cubes and pulse about 10 times, until the largest butter pieces are the size of small peas.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-1"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Add the ice-cold water and pulse just until the dough comes together.","name":"Add the ice-cold water and pulse just until the dough comes together.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-2"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface and form it into a ball. Cut the ball in half and shape each half into a round disk. Wrap one of the disks in plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator.","name":"Transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface and form it into a ball. Cut the ball in half and shape each half into a round disk. Wrap one of the disks in plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-3"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"On a lightly floured work surface, roll the second disk out to a 12-inch round and transfer it to a deep-dish pie pan. (This is easily done by wrapping the dough round around your rolling pin to help move it.)","name":"On a lightly floured work surface, roll the second disk out to a 12-inch round and transfer it to a deep-dish pie pan. (This is easily done by wrapping the dough round around your rolling pin to help move it.)","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-4"}]},{"@type":"HowToSection","name":"Assemble the Pie","itemListElement":[{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"By this time, the apples should have released some of their juices. Stir the apple mixture to make sure everything is well combined and then pour the apples and their juices into the pie crust.","name":"By this time, the apples should have released some of their juices. Stir the apple mixture to make sure everything is well combined and then pour the apples and their juices into the pie crust.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-0"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Roll out the second pie dough disk to a 12-inch round. You can place the dough round on top of the pie as is, or you can make a lattice-top pie crust. If putting the full dough round on top of the pie, cut a few slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape as the pie bakes.","name":"Roll out the second pie dough disk to a 12-inch round. You can place the dough round on top of the pie as is, or you can make a lattice-top pie crust. If putting the full dough round on top of the pie, cut a few slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape as the pie bakes.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-1"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"To make a lattice top pie crust (see step-by-step photos in the post above): Cut the second dough round into \u00bd-inch strips. Place the longest strip down the center of the pie. Reserving every other dough strip to go in the other direction on the pie, lay strips across the pie with just a little bit of space between. Then weave in strips going the opposite direction on the pie.","name":"To make a lattice top pie crust (see step-by-step photos in the post above): Cut the second dough round into \u00bd-inch strips. Place the longest strip down the center of the pie. Reserving every other dough strip to go in the other direction on the pie, lay strips across the pie with just a little bit of space between. Then weave in strips going the opposite direction on the pie.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-2"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Trim the edges of the pie crust so that there is a \u00bd-inch overhang over the edge of the pie dish. Fold the overhang under itself and flute\/crimp the edges of the crust as desired.","name":"Trim the edges of the pie crust so that there is a \u00bd-inch overhang over the edge of the pie dish. Fold the overhang under itself and flute\/crimp the edges of the crust as desired.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-3"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Brush the pie crust with milk (to help with browning and to help the coarse sugar stick) and sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.","name":"Brush the pie crust with milk (to help with browning and to help the coarse sugar stick) and sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-4"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Refrigerate pie for 30 minutes before baking.","name":"Refrigerate pie for 30 minutes before baking.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-5"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Meanwhile, preheat oven to 400\u00b0 F with a rack in the lower third of the oven.","name":"Meanwhile, preheat oven to 400\u00b0 F with a rack in the lower third of the oven.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-6"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Bake the pie at 400\u00b0 for 20 minutes, then reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0 F. Continue baking the pie for 40-50 minutes more, until the filling is bubbly. Check on the pie partway through the baking time and tent it with foil as needed to prevent the crust from over-browning (to tent with foil means to loosely cover the pie by laying a sheet of foil over the top).","name":"Bake the pie at 400\u00b0 for 20 minutes, then reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0 F. Continue baking the pie for 40-50 minutes more, until the filling is bubbly. Check on the pie partway through the baking time and tent it with foil as needed to prevent the crust from over-browning (to tent with foil means to loosely cover the pie by laying a sheet of foil over the top).","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-7"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Let the pie cool at room temperature for at least 2 hours before serving to allow the filling to thicken.","name":"Let the pie cool at room temperature for at least 2 hours before serving to allow the filling to thicken.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-8"},{"@type":"HowToStep","text":"Store pie at room temperature for up to one day, or in the refrigerator, covered with plastic wrap, for up to 5 days. Pie can also be frozen, wrapped tightly, for up to 3 months.","name":"Store pie at room temperature for up to one day, or in the refrigerator, covered with plastic wrap, for up to 5 days. Pie can also be frozen, wrapped tightly, for up to 3 months.","url":"https:\/\/kristineskitchenblog.com\/my-favorite-apple-pie\/#wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-9"}]}],"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingValue":"5","ratingCount":"41"},"recipeCategory":["Dessert"],"recipeCuisine":["American"],"keywords":"apple pie, apple pie filling, apple pie recipe, homemade, lattice pie crust","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","servingSize":"1 \/8 pie","calories":"470 kcal","carbohydrateContent":"62 g","proteinContent":"5 g","fatContent":"24 g","saturatedFatContent":"15 g","cholesterolContent":"61 mg","sodiumContent":"226 mg","fiberContent":"4 g","sugarContent":"28 g"}}</script>

<article class="post single-post-content">

	<div class="breadcrumb"><span><span><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/">Home</a></span> » <span><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/category/desserts/">Dessert Recipes</a></span> » <span class="breadcrumb_last" aria-current="page">Apple Pie Recipe</span></span></div> 	
 	<h1 class="post-title">Apple Pie Recipe</h1>

 	<div class="post-meta">
		<div class="wprm-recipe wprm-recipe-snippet wprm-recipe-template-custom-snippet"><a href="#recipe" data-recipe="28038" style="color: #333333;" class="wprm-recipe-jump wprm-recipe-link wprm-jump-to-recipe-shortcode wprm-block-text-normal wprm-jump-smooth-scroll" data-smooth-scroll="500"><span class="wprm-recipe-icon wprm-recipe-jump-icon"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24"><g class="nc-icon-wrapper" fill="#333333"><path data-color="color-2" d="M9,2h6c0.6,0,1-0.4,1-1s-0.4-1-1-1H9C8.4,0,8,0.4,8,1S8.4,2,9,2z"></path> <path fill="#333333" d="M16,11V5c0-0.6-0.4-1-1-1H9C8.4,4,8,4.4,8,5v6H1.9L12,23.6L22.1,11H16z"></path></g></svg></span> Jump to Recipe</a><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/wprm_print/28038" style="color: #333333;" class="wprm-recipe-print wprm-recipe-link wprm-print-recipe-shortcode wprm-block-text-normal" data-recipe-id="28038" data-template="" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Print Recipe</a></div>			 
				

	</div>
	  	
	<div class="post-content">
		<p>This <strong>A</strong><strong>pple Pie Recipe</strong> is easy to make from scratch! With a flaky, buttery pie crust and a sweet homemade apple pie filling, this apple pie is guaranteed to be a favorite. It’s perfect for the holidays or a weekend dessert.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" data-skip-lazy="" class="alignnone wp-image-50912 size-full" title="This classic Apple Pie Recipe makes the BEST old fashioned apple pie from scratch! This easy pie has a flaky, buttery pie crust and a sweet homemade apple pie filling. With simple directions for how to make apple pie, including which type of apples to use. It's perfect for the holidays, Thanksgiving or a weekend dessert." src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?resize=1200%2C1800&ssl=1" alt="Slice of apple pie on a plate with a fork with whole pie in background." width="1200" height="1800" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?w=1200&ssl=1 1200w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?resize=500%2C750&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?resize=768%2C1152&ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?resize=700%2C1050&ssl=1 700w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/apple-pie-recipe-592.jpg?resize=1024%2C1536&ssl=1 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></p>
<p>Homemade apple pie is a classic <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/category/desserts/">dessert recipe</a> that’s especially perfect for fall. But really, who wouldn’t love a slice of apple pie any time of year?</p>
<p>Making a pie from scratch can seem difficult, but it is actually really easy. If making pie dough from scratch intimidates you, don’t worry. I will walk you through the simple steps so that you can make your own scrumptious apple pie from scratch.</p>
<p>As I was testing this apple pie recipe, my whole family kept raving that it’s the best apple pie they’ve ever eaten. You’ll have to tell me which you like more, because I just can’t decide:  the juicy cinnamon-spiced apple pie filling or the buttery, flaky pie crust. This recipe is so good that I based my <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/dutch-apple-pie/">Dutch Apple Pie</a> recipe off of it!</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="alignnone wp-image-50913 size-full" title="This classic Apple Pie Recipe makes the BEST old fashioned apple pie from scratch! This easy pie has a flaky, buttery pie crust and a sweet homemade apple pie filling. With simple directions for how to make apple pie, including which type of apples to use. <p>For Thanksgiving and the holidays, this delicious <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/classic-pumpkin-pie/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Pumpkin Pie Recipe</a> is my other favorite (and it’s really easy, too!). You’ll also love my <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/blackberry-pie/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Blackberry Pie</a> and <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/cherry-pie-with-almond-and-oat-crumble/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Cherry Pie</a> recipes. For an easy-to-make apple dessert try my <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/apple-crisp/">Apple Crisp</a> recipe. <span id="more-4468"></span></p>
<div>
<h2>Best Apples for Apple Pie</h2>
<p>The best apple pie starts with good baking apples. You want to use apples that are firm enough to hold up to the heat of baking, so that they don’t cook down into mush.</p>
<p>I like to use a combination of sweet and tart apples in apple pie for the best flavor and texture. My favorite is a combination of Granny Smith and Honeycrisp apples. The Granny Smiths add tartness, and the Honeycrisps are on the sweeter side, so you get the perfect balance of sweet and tart flavors.</p>
<ul>
<li>Tart varieties of apples that are best for pie include Granny Smith, Northern Spy and Cripps Pink.</li>
<li>Sweeter varieties of apples that are best for pie include Honeycrisp, Jonagold, Golden Delicious, Braeburn, Pink Lady, Crispin (Mutsu), Jazz and Fuji.</li>
<li>Learn more about <a href="https://bestapples.com/varieties-information/varieties/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">apple types</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div>
<h2>Perfect Pie Crust</h2>
<p>Another key to the best apple pie is a buttery, flaky pie crust. We’ll be using my easy all-butter <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/pie-crust-recipe/">Pie Crust Recipe</a> – you don’t have to chill the dough before rolling it out, and it rolls out like a dream. The trick to the best flaky pie crust is to use very cold butter and ice-cold water, and to work quickly to keep the butter cold. But don’t stress! You really can’t mess up this pie crust.</p>
<p>I like to make pie dough in my food processor, because it is quick and easy. You can also make the pie crust by hand, using a pastry blender. The steps to making the pie crust are simple:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Combine the dry ingredients:</strong> flour, granulated sugar and salt. You can use the pulse function of your food processor to mix them together.</li>
<li><strong>Cut in the butter:</strong> Make sure to use butter that is cold, straight from the refrigerator. You can even freeze your butter for a few minutes to make it colder. Cut the butter into cubes and add it to the food processor. Pulse about 10 times, until the largest pieces of butter are the size of peas.</li>
<li><strong>Add ice-cold water:</strong> Pulse until the dough begins to come together.</li>
</ol>

<h2>How to Make Apple Pie</h2>
<p>Here’s an overview of the simple steps to making this apple pie. Or, jump straight to the full <a href="#recipe">apple pie recipe</a>.</p>
<h3>Apple Pie Filling</h3>
<p>This easy apple pie recipe starts with my easy homemade apple pie filling. The first step is to peel and slice your apples. You want the apple slices to be about 1/4-inch thick. You will need about 8 cups of sliced apples (6-8 apples) to fill a deep dish pie dish.</p>
<p>Place the sliced apples in a large bowl. To the bowl, add the rest of the apple pie filling ingredients:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Vanilla Extract:</strong> A little bit of vanilla extract adds sweetness and flavor to the pie.</li>
<li><strong>All-Purpose Flour:</strong> The flour helps to thicken the pie filling.</li>
<li><strong>Granulated Sugar:</strong> You can adjust the amount of sugar depending on the sweetness of your apples and how sweet you like your pie.</li>
<li><strong>Brown Sugar:</strong> I like to use brown sugar as well as granulated sugar because it adds a richer flavor with caramel notes.</li>
<li><strong>Cinnamon:</strong> A little bit of cinnamon is essential for the best apple pie filling!</li>
<li><strong>Nutmeg:</strong> You’ll add just 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg, for flavor.</li>
<li><strong>Salt:</strong> Salt is essential in baking to balance out the sweetness. It enhances all of the flavors!</li>
</ul>

<p>Stir to combine the ingredients. Then you’ll let the filling sit at room temperature while you make the pie crust. As the filling rests, the sugar will start to bring out the juices from the apples. You’ll stir the filling again after it sits to make sure everything is well combined.</p>
<h3>Assemble the Pie</h3>
<p>The pie crust recipe makes enough dough for a top and bottom pie crust. You’ll cut the dough in half and shape it into two disks. Refrigerate one disk for the top crust, and roll out the other for the bottom crust. Fit the bottom crust into your pie dish so it reaches all the way up the sides of the dish.</p>

<p>Give the apple filling a stir and transfer it to the bottom crust in the pie dish. If it seems like your apples won’t fit, use your fingers to arrange them a bit and help them better fill the space.</p>
<p>Roll out the second pie crust for the top of the pie. You can place it on the pie whole, you can make a lattice pie crust (see below for step by step photos), or you can use a cookie cutter and arrange the dough shapes on top of the pie filling. If placing the dough round on the pie whole, be sure to cut a few slits in the top dough so that steam can escape as the pie bakes.</p>
<p>Lightly brush the top crust with milk or an egg wash. This helps the crust to brown nicely. (I usually use milk instead of an egg wash, which is a combination of an egg and milk or water, because I find it easier and just as effective).</p>
<p>While your oven preheats, chill the pie in your refrigerator to make sure the crust is cold. You’ll bake your apple pie for 20 minutes at 400° F and then another 40-50 minutes at 350° F. Check on the pie after it has baked for about 30-40 minutes total, and cover it loosely with foil to prevent the crust from browning too much. The pie is done when the filling is bubbly.</p>

<h2>How to Make a Lattice Pie Crust</h2>
<p>A lattice-top pie crust is the name for the woven crust that you see on the top of this apple pie. It’s fun and pretty to make a lattice top crust for your pie.</p>
<p>To make a lattice pie crust, roll out the dough for the top of the pie into a 12-inch diameter circle. Use a sharp knife, pizza cutter or pastry wheel to cut the dough circle into ½-inch strips.</p>

It's perfect for the holidays, Thanksgiving or a weekend dessert." src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?resize=1200%2C1800&ssl=1" alt="Rolled out pie dough round cut into strips." width="1200" height="1800" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?w=1200&ssl=1 1200w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?resize=500%2C750&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?resize=600%2C900&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?resize=768%2C1152&ssl=1 768w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/lattice-pie-crust-1-7124.jpg?resize=1024%2C1536&ssl=1 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></noscript></p>
<p>Using every other strip from the circle, arrange half of the dough strips going one direction across the pie. Leave a little bit of space in between each strip.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28271 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%201415%20950'%3E%3C/svg%3E" alt="Two photos of weaving a lattice pie crust: strips covering pie in one direction https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-1.jpg?resize=600%2C403&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-1.jpg?resize=768%2C516&ssl=1 768w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" data-lazy-src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-1.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" /><noscript><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28271 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-1.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" alt="Two photos of weaving a lattice pie crust: strips covering pie in one direction and then weaving the first strip of dough." width="1415" height="950" /></noscript></p>
<p>Weave the other half of the dough strips through the first set, over and under, pulling back the first set of strips as needed to weave. I find it easiest to start in the center of the pie when weaving, and pull back every other of the first set of dough strips.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28272 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%201415%20950'%3E%3C/svg%3E" alt="Weaving more strips of dough into a lattice pie crust." width="1415" height="950" data-lazy-srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?w=1415&ssl=1 1415w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=500%2C336&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=600%2C403&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=768%2C516&ssl=1 768w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" data-lazy-src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" /><noscript><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28272 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" alt="Weaving more strips of dough into a lattice pie crust." width="1415" height="950" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?w=1415&ssl=1 1415w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=500%2C336&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=600%2C403&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-2.jpg?resize=768%2C516&ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></noscript></p>
<p>Once you finish weaving in strips on one side of the pie, begin weaving the remaining strips of dough on the other side of the pie.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28273 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%201415%20950'%3E%3C/svg%3E" alt="Weaving in the final strips of dough to make a lattice pie crust." width="1415" height="950" data-lazy-srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?w=1415&ssl=1 1415w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=500%2C336&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=600%2C403&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=768%2C516&ssl=1 768w" data-lazy-sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" data-lazy-src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" /><noscript><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-28273 size-full" title="How to make a lattice pie crust." src="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=1415%2C950&ssl=1" alt="Weaving in the final strips of dough to make a lattice pie crust." width="1415" height="950" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?w=1415&ssl=1 1415w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=500%2C336&ssl=1 500w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=600%2C403&ssl=1 600w, https://i0.wp.com/kristineskitchenblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Lattice-Pie-Crust-3.jpg?resize=768%2C516&ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" data-recalc-dims="1" /></noscript></p>
<p>When you are finished weaving, trim off any excess dough from around the edges of the pie. Fold the edges under and crimp or flute as desired.</p>

<div>
<h2>Make Ahead Instructions</h2>
<p>If you want to make this apple pie ahead for your Christmas or holiday meal, I recommend baking it the day before, letting it cool completely, and then storing it at room temperature, wrapped tightly with plastic wrap. To make two days ahead, cool completely, wrap tightly, and store in the refrigerator. Take the pie out of the refrigerator 1-2 hours before serving to let it come to room temperature.</p>
<p><strong>To store apple pie:</strong> You can store your apple pie at room temperature for one day. This apple pie can be stored in the refrigerator for 4-5 days.</p>
<p><strong>To freeze apple pie:</strong> Let the pie cool completely and then wrap it tightly. Freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw for 24 hours in the refrigerator before serving.</p>
</div>
<div class="custom-box">
<h2>Apple Pie Recipe Tips</h2>
<ul>
<li>This recipe makes enough filling for a deep dish apple pie. If your pie plate is small, consider reducing the number of apples.</li>
<li>You can use a store bought pie crust instead of homemade to save time.</li>
<li>You can adjust the amount of sugar in the pie filling depending on how sweet your apples are and how sweet you like your pie.</li>
<li>I like to sprinkle some coarse turbinado sugar on the top crust because it makes the pie look pretty. It also adds a delicious sweet crunch to the top crust. Sprinkle it on after brushing with milk or egg wash.</li>
<li>Be sure to check on the pie partway through the baking time and cover it with foil to keep the crust from over-browning.</li>
<li>You’ll want to plan ahead so that you can let the pie cool for at least 2 hours before serving. As the pie cools, the filling will thicken up, making it easier to serve.</li>
</ul>
</div>

<p>This apple pie from scratch is one of our very favorite <a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com/tag/apple/">apple recipes</a>. It’s especially delicious served with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Give this recipe a try and then leave a comment below to let me know how it turned out!</p>

<style type="text/css">ul.wprm-advanced-list-156 li:before {background-color: #78c0b7;color: #3e4146;width: 24px;height: 24px;font-size: 12px;line-height: 12px;}</style><div class="wprm-recipe-instructions-container wprm-recipe-28038-instructions-container wprm-block-text-normal" data-recipe="28038"><h3 class="wprm-recipe-header wprm-recipe-instructions-header wprm-block-text-uppercase wprm-align-left wprm-header-decoration-line wprm-header-has-actions" style="">Instructions<div class="wprm-decoration-line" style="border-color: #3e4146"></div> </h3><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Make the Apple Filling</h4><ul class="wprm-advanced-list wprm-advanced-list-reset wprm-advanced-list-156 wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-0-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Place the peeled, sliced apples in a large bowl.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-0-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Add the vanilla, ¼ cup flour, granulated sugar and brown sugar to the bowl with the apples. Sprinkle the cinnamon, nutmeg and salt over the apples. Stir to combine. Set aside while you make the pie crust.</span></div></li></ul></div><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Make the Pie Crust</h4><ul class="wprm-advanced-list wprm-advanced-list-reset wprm-advanced-list-156 wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Place the flour, sugar and salt in the bowl of a food processor fitted with the steel blade. (Alternatively, the pie crust dough can be made by hand in a large bowl using a pastry cutter or your fingers to cut in the butter.)</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Pulse to combine the dry ingredients. Add the cold butter cubes and pulse about 10 times, until the largest butter pieces are the size of small peas.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-2" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Add the ice-cold water and pulse just until the dough comes together.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-3" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface and form it into a ball. Cut the ball in half and shape each half into a round disk. Wrap one of the disks in plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-1-4" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">On a lightly floured work surface, roll the second disk out to a 12-inch round and transfer it to a deep-dish pie pan. (This is easily done by wrapping the dough round around your rolling pin to help move it.)</span></div></li></ul></div><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-group"><h4 class="wprm-recipe-group-name wprm-recipe-instruction-group-name wprm-block-text-bold">Assemble the Pie</h4><ul class="wprm-advanced-list wprm-advanced-list-reset wprm-advanced-list-156 wprm-recipe-instructions"><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-0" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">By this time, the apples should have released some of their juices. Stir the apple mixture to make sure everything is well combined and then pour the apples and their juices into the pie crust.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-1" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Roll out the second pie dough disk to a 12-inch round. You can place the dough round on top of the pie as is, or you can make a lattice-top pie crust. If putting the full dough round on top of the pie, cut a few slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape as the pie bakes.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-2" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">To make a lattice top pie crust (see step-by-step photos in the post above): Cut the second dough round into ½-inch strips. Place the longest strip down the center of the pie. Reserving every other dough strip to go in the other direction on the pie, lay strips across the pie with just a little bit of space between. Then weave in strips going the opposite direction on the pie. </span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-3" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Trim the edges of the pie crust so that there is a ½-inch overhang over the edge of the pie dish. Fold the overhang under itself and flute/crimp the edges of the crust as desired.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-4" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Brush the pie crust with milk (to help with browning and to help the coarse sugar stick) and sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-5" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Refrigerate pie for 30 minutes before baking.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-6" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Meanwhile, preheat oven to 400° F with a rack in the lower third of the oven.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-7" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Bake the pie at 400° for 20 minutes, then reduce oven temperature to 350° F. Continue baking the pie for 40-50 minutes more, until the filling is bubbly. Check on the pie partway through the baking time and tent it with foil as needed to prevent the crust from over-browning (to tent with foil means to loosely cover the pie by laying a sheet of foil over the top).</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-8" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Let the pie cool at room temperature for at least 2 hours before serving to allow the filling to thicken.</span></div></li><li id="wprm-recipe-28038-step-2-9" class="wprm-recipe-instruction" style="list-style-type: none;"><div class="wprm-recipe-instruction-text" style="margin-bottom: 5px";><span style="display: block;">Store pie at room temperature for up to one day, or in the refrigerator, covered with plastic wrap, for up to 5 days. Pie can also be frozen, wrapped tightly, for up to 3 months.</span></div></li></ul></div></div>
<div id="recipe-video"></div><div id="wprm-recipe-video-container-28038" class="wprm-recipe-video-container"><div class="wprm-recipe-video"><div class="mv-video-target mv-video-id-h1plnmvurqupsxc6k0tq" data-video-id="h1plnmvurqupsxc6k0tq"  data-volume="70"  data-ratio="16:9" ></div></div></div>
<div class="wprm-recipe-notes-container wprm-block-text-normal"><h3 class="wprm-recipe-header wprm-recipe-notes-header wprm-block-text-uppercase wprm-align-left wprm-header-decoration-line" style="">Notes<div class="wprm-decoration-line" style="border-color: #3e4146"></div></h3><div class="wprm-recipe-notes"><ul>
<li>I find that this pie is plenty sweet when made with 1/4 cup granulated sugar plus 1/4 cup brown sugar. Depending on the sweetness of your apples and how sweet you like your pie, you can adjust the amount of sugar.</li>
<li>This recipe makes enough filling for a deep dish apple pie. If your pie plate is small, consider reducing the number of apples.</li>
</ul></div></div>

<p>I followed recipe exactly but used a sugar replacement (= amounts to regular sugar) and used our spartan apples from our tree.  The non salt butter crust is amazing!  Sprinkled organic coconut palm sugar on top of crust just enough to show some granular color on crust.  Definitely recommend this recipe!<br />
This is a great recipe.    Kristine I’ll be trying more of your meal recipes!</p>

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">

                <time datetime="2020-05-20T10:22:47-07:00">

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-47832' data-commentid="47832" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-47832" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Şeyma" aria-label='Reply to Şeyma'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hi kristine your pie looks perfect. I am going to bake this tomorrow. Can i make the crust dough now and store it at the refrigerator?</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    <ul class="children">
	    <li class="comment byuser comment-author-kristineskitchen bypostauthor even depth-2" id="li-comment-47841">
	        <div id="comment-47841" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-05-20T17:30:29-07:00">
                May 20, 2020 @ 5:30 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-47841' data-commentid="47841" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-47841" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Yes, the dough can be stored in the refrigerator. Form each half of the dough into a round disk and wrap it in plastic wrap before refrigerating. You may have to let it sit out for 10 to 15 minutes to take the chill off before rolling it out.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

			<p>Thank you for this recipe so detailed and easy to follow. I forgot to refrigerate the pie for 30 mins before oven but they seem fine. I made not one but two because I was home alone with 16 apples and I may have added 1/3c of whiskey to the sauce mix .. can’t wait to try them ?</p>

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">

                <time datetime="2020-08-30T13:55:06-07:00">
                August 30, 2020 @ 1:55 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49613' data-commentid="49613" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-49613" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Sheila Brausey" aria-label='Reply to Sheila Brausey'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hello i was wondering if i can make the pie filling then freeze it to use in a pie look later on. If so, are there any tips? Thanks</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    <ul class="children">
	    <li class="comment byuser comment-author-kristineskitchen bypostauthor even depth-2" id="li-comment-49615">
	        <div id="comment-49615" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-08-30T14:42:09-07:00">
                August 30, 2020 @ 2:42 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49615' data-commentid="49615" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-49615" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>I haven’t tried freezing this, but I think it would freeze well. My only concern would be that the apples might brown, so you might want to toss them in a little bit of lemon juice (1-2 tablespoons) before adding the rest of the filling ingredients.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
	    <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-50028">
	        <div id="comment-50028" class="comment">
				
				            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong>leigh</strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-09-17T18:41:45-07:00">
                September 17, 2020 @ 6:41 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-50028' data-commentid="50028" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-50028" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to leigh" aria-label='Reply to leigh'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>i made this recipe before and the crust stuck to the bottom of the pie dish terribly. what to you recommend doing to stop this from happening again? i am going to try it again tomorrow and am wondering what to do differently.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    <ul class="children">
	    <li class="comment byuser comment-author-kristineskitchen bypostauthor even depth-2" id="li-comment-50067">
	        <div id="comment-50067" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-09-20T15:35:54-07:00">
                September 20, 2020 @ 3:35 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-50067' data-commentid="50067" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-50067" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hmmm, I’ve never had that happen. What type of pie dish did you use? I use a ceramic pie dish. Did you happen to press the crust down into the pie dish? I recommend just laying the crust in the dish without pressing it down. You could also try greasing the pie dish, although I never do and my crust doesn’t stick. I hope that helps!</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

<p>I followed everything to a T, plus the extra quarter cup of sugar. I was so very pleased with this recipe. The directions were so simple to follow and the dough was  easy to work with. This was such a fool-proof and decadent recipe. Absolutely splendid!</p>

			<p>Hi Kristine,</p>

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">

                <time datetime="2020-11-08T14:44:06-08:00">

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51087' data-commentid="51087" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51087" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>I sometimes dot my pies with butter, but for this apple pie I’ve found that it just doesn’t need it. It’s absolutely delicious without the extra butter, so I skip that step. 🙂 I hope you’re pie turned out wonderfully!</p>

                <time datetime="2020-11-05T06:14:28-08:00">

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-50985' data-commentid="50985" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-50985" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Brenda" aria-label='Reply to Brenda'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Suggestions on how to keep the crust from sticking to the pie dish so it doesn’t look terrible when you cut the slices? Thank you. I am excited to try this. Cooking for new family in a new house!</p>

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-11-08T14:25:02-08:00">
                November 8, 2020 @ 2:25 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51080' data-commentid="51080" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51080" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>I never have a problem with this crust sticking to the pie dish. I recommend that you not press the crust into the dish, just lay it in gently, both on the bottom and around the sides.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

</li><!-- #comment-## -->
	    <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-51017">
	        <div id="comment-51017" class="comment">
				
				            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong>Sarah</strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-11-06T08:53:47-08:00">
                November 6, 2020 @ 8:53 am                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51017' data-commentid="51017" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51017" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Sarah" aria-label='Reply to Sarah'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Can you make the crust in advance and freeze it? </p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    <ul class="children">
	    <li class="comment byuser comment-author-kristineskitchen bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="li-comment-51047">
	        <div id="comment-51047" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-11-07T06:37:59-08:00">
                November 7, 2020 @ 6:37 am                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51047' data-commentid="51047" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51047" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Yes. Shape and wrap the pie crust well in plastic wrap before freezing. If you don’t want to shape it first, wrap the disc of dough tightly before freezing. Defrost the disc of dough the day before use in the refrigerator so it can be shaped.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    </li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51019' data-commentid="51019" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51019" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Dawn" aria-label='Reply to Dawn'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hello,<br />
Can I make the pie crust one day in advance of the filling/baking process?<br />
Dawn</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 —

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51046' data-commentid="51046" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51046" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Yes, you can make the pie crust the day before. Shape the pie crust into a disc then wrap it tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51570' data-commentid="51570" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51570" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Stephanie" aria-label='Reply to Stephanie'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>I just baked the pie using your recipe exactly and it looks delicious!! Question – if I leave it out tonight and want to reheat tomorrow, what’s the best way?</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->
	 
	    <ul class="children">
	    <li class="comment byuser comment-author-kristineskitchen bypostauthor even depth-2" id="li-comment-51588">
	        <div id="comment-51588" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2020-11-26T07:34:27-08:00">
                November 26, 2020 @ 7:34 am                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51588' data-commentid="51588" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51588" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>You can warm it in the oven at 350 degrees, for 10-15 minutes until warm. Cover the crust if needed to prevent browning. This pie is also so delicious served at room temperature, so you might also try that. If you are warming individual slices, the microwave works great. Enjoy!</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

<p>This is a great recipe. And easy to follow instructions. I made it three times this thanksgiving. Two times I used a hand mixer for the dough, one time was just by hand. </p>
<p>I notice the first time I made it with hand mixer, it was perfect! The one by only hand not so much. </p>
<p>I think for my next go round because I just LOVE this recipe, I am going to invest in food processor. Thank you again!! This is me and my sons favorite dessert </p>

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51719' data-commentid="51719" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-51719" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Liz" aria-label='Reply to Liz'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>This is a great recipe! I’ve never been a pie person but this might make me a convert. The only thing I changed was straining the seasoned apples and reducing the liquid before adding it back. Delicious! </p>

<p>Made this for my Father-In-Law yesterday for his birthday – he loves apple pie and said this was “the best one he’s had in a loooooong time”! I always get nervous not having tasted a recipe before giving it to someone and I am so glad he loves it – thanks so much for a stellar recipe 🙂</p>

<p>I just baked the pie and everything looks good except. We haven’t eaten it yet but when I tried it, it tasted a bit bitter. I added the recommended salt amount but I think that made it bitter instead balancing it as you said. Or do you think it could’ve been the cinnamon?</p>

			<p>Hi Jasmine,<br />

<p>I’ve made this recipe several times now since I’ve had an abundance of apples. Friends and family love it and thought it was store bought since I transported it in a disposable plastic pie container leftover from something else. You provided excellent instructions, especially the lattice top, which makes it look super fancy. Thank you.</p>

            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">

                <time datetime="2021-09-09T17:42:08-07:00">
                September 9, 2021 @ 5:42 pm                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-57927' data-commentid="57927" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-57927" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Annie" aria-label='Reply to Annie'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>OMG, this pie is delicious! I was given a bushel of apples. I ended up making 6 pies. I didn’t have time to make the crust, so I used store bought. My daughter-in-law is vegan and was able to find a crust for her and instead of using milk, I used aquafaba (the liquid from a can of chickpeas) and it browned beautifully. Thank you so much for a wonderful recipe.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-59328' data-commentid="59328" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-59328" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Rhonda Keelin" aria-label='Reply to Rhonda Keelin'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hi Kristine, Rhonda here, may I ask why you refrigerated the pie befor baking ?                 <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-59339' data-commentid="59339" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-59339" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine" aria-label='Reply to Kristine'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Hi Rhonda, Thank you for your kind words. I refrigerate the pie for about 30 minutes before baking because I find that it makes a flakier crust. You can skip the refrigeration step if you prefer. The pie will turn out delicious either way. Enjoy!</p>

                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-69855' data-commentid="69855" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-69855" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Marian Montano" aria-label='Reply to Marian Montano'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>This is the best apple pie I have ever made.  The filling and crust were perfection.  The recipe is so well written it really is fool proof.  I  cannot wait to make it for Thanksgiving. <p>Last Saturday, I decided to make an Apple Pie for the first time in my life. I have never baked any goodies before. This was the best recipe! It was so easy to follow and everything went so smoothly! Thank you so much for this recipe and for making me one happy lady! I had to freeze the rest after eating two slices because I was about to eat the whole thing in one sitting! </p>
<p>The crust was so buttery, fluffy and crispy. I am lactose intolerant and did feel the ramifications LOL. So next time, I might try this with vegan butter and brown sugar.</p>

	        <div id="comment-70888" class="comment">
				
				<img alt='' src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%2060%2060'%3E%3C/svg%3E" data-lazy-srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async' data-lazy-src="https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg"/><noscript><img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=60&d=blank&r=pg' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/69abf391be0b7395ba04c8a4cbaa2aaf?s=120&d=blank&r=pg 2x' class='avatar avatar-60 photo' height='60' width='60' decoding='async'/></noscript>            
            		
            <div class="post-meta comment-meta">
            	<strong><a href="https://kristineskitchenblog.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Kristine Rosenblatt</a></strong>            	 — 
                <time datetime="2022-11-20T07:00:27-08:00">
                November 20, 2022 @ 7:00 am                </time>
                
                <a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-70888' data-commentid="70888" data-postid="4468" data-belowelement="comment-70888" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Kristine Rosenblatt" aria-label='Reply to Kristine Rosenblatt'>Reply</a>                            </div><!-- .comment-meta -->
			
			<p>Liquids boil at a lower temperature at high altitude, so that may be why it was bubbling sooner. Generally, though, fruit pies may take a little longer to cook at high altitude, since it can take longer for the fruit to soften.</p>

	        </div><!-- #comment-## -->

			<p>Hi Lisa,<br />

<p>I made this pie for thanksgiving and everyone loved it. I am making it again for Christmas Eve dinner. Loved how easy it is and so moist. The crust was perfect. I didn’t do a lattice but did a full cover with slits. It bubbled over do trying it on a baking tray this next go around.  Best recipe i have ever made. Its idiot proof!</p>
